How does a pseudodog attack? It has some special type of attack. Dogs have their own pattern, tushkanos have theirs — those are clear enough. But the pseudo has its own particular principle. Figure it out, and you'll always have the upper hand against it... \nAt the end of summer, in the evenings, we used to bake potatoes in bonfires in the yard with the guys. You poke them with a stick, and they're already all charred. But you won't find potatoes tastier than that. I can still remember the taste. There were lots of guys, but not enough potatoes — well, raw ones were plentiful, but once they were ready to eat, there wasn't enough for everyone around one fire. You couldn't just sit alone by your own fire and bake your own potatoes — that's no fun. So we had to draw lots: matches, bottle caps, whatever — like, “Who hits the tree on the first try gets a potato.” Usually the older guys won, the younger ones almost always lost. Sometimes I got lucky, sometimes I didn't. But with matches I quickly figured out the principle — usually the edge ones are more often at the edge or the middle, so you shouldn't pull from the very edge, but not from the very middle either. In the “hit the tree” game there was also a principle: the main thing was not to go first, but to wait. The first ones usually missed... something like that, I don't remember exactly why. The main thing I understood back then was this: in any game you need to understand the principle — then it becomes clear what to do to win more often... The Zone has its own principle of survival too. You need to understand it if you want to keep winning longer.

There are plenty of smartasses in the Zone. Everyone tries to show off, and the biggest show-offs start lecturing you and teaching you how to live. Lower your weapon, don't do this, don't do that, don't steal, don't mess with soldiers... Educators, my ass... \nMy mother was always trying to raise me. My parents didn't interest me much in general. I don't remember my father at all. My mother said he was never around in the first place. Later she tried to arrange her life somehow, and a stepfather appeared. I was afraid of him. He was a harsh man — anything wrong and you'd get a cuff on the back of the head, or even a slap in the face. And his palm was huge — could easily hide half a loaf of bread in his fist. At first my stepfather tried to please me in every way, but when he realized I didn't respect him at all and was slipping out of his control, he started “teaching” me life, “raising” me his way. Then, when we moved to another city, thank God, he took off somewhere. Supposedly even drank himself to ruin, but I didn't see that — my mother told me. My mother still made some attempts to raise me, but I didn't like it, and in general I didn't want to take any part in that process. So we came to an unspoken agreement — I'm on my own, she's on her own... And I like that position here too: I'm on my own, and everyone else can go to hell!..

How do you ensure financial independence in the Zone if everything you really need is traded for artifacts? Artifacts aren't mushrooms — today they're here, tomorrow they're gone. It's like a lottery, like a game — lucky or unlucky. What kind of independence is that, when everything depends not even on luck, but on the whims of the Zone... \nBack in my school years I got my first pleasant taste of winning. A slot machine hall opened in our town. They called it a club, but in reality it was just packed with one-armed bandits. People flooded in, and of course I tried it too. At first it was hit or miss. And then one evening I got lucky. I got several bonuses and left the club with a brand-new crisp bill. The next evening, of course, I was there again. I bought tokens with everything I had, fed them into the machine, and three hours later I won five times as much. I went home in style — by taxi. It seemed to me I'd found the winning formula: change the game every ten minutes, and once you get a certain amount, cash out and sit down at another machine. When on my third visit to the club I “took the bank” again, I had an epiphany: two or three times a week you could calmly earn a living. In a month you could make more than my mother earned at her little factory. From then on I became a regular at the club. I was lucky. The “system” worked... for a while. Sometimes it failed, but I didn't get discouraged — at least I had become financially independent. Or so it seemed to me...

In the Zone, as everywhere else, there are those who build their lives on other people's gambling. When you see some stalker staking his last on the line, you can't help but smile. But how am I any better?.. \nI always liked games, liked that anticipation of luck, that feeling of fortune... But my first big loss horrified me. Losing almost everything I'd managed to save in one evening, I was baffled. How could that be? Where did I make a mistake? The money I'd won flew away very quickly. My “system” failed, and a dark streak began. My own money ran out, I started borrowing from friends. I didn't want to take money from my mother, and there wasn't much to take anyway — in one evening I'd lose many times more than she could give me. For the first time in my life I realized what dependence on others was like, dependence on money. But I couldn't go and slave away at some office like everyone else. Work was boring routine, and I needed my dose of excitement. After another loss I left the club on unsteady legs and dragged myself home along a night street. My head hurt, my mood was rock bottom, hopelessness. There wasn't a penny in my wallet. I followed some woman for half a block, seriously deciding to attack her, take her wallet, and go back to the club. Thank God I managed to restrain my instincts then. After that, for some time I thought about only one thing — where to get money... But one way or another those thoughts faded into the background — I got drafted into the army, and there you don't really have time to think about money...

Poor Zone soldiers, what kind of service do they have here... Boredom, no entertainment, no leave. So they shoot dogs and tushkanos out of boredom. Arrange firing sessions... \nI know there are people who actually want to go into the army, even consider it their duty. That wasn't me. I didn't want the army and dodged it as long as I could. I kept hoping for luck — maybe they'd forget about me, maybe they didn't need me... They didn't forget. I considered that time crossed out of my life. What could be interesting or exciting there? Boredom. The only entertainment was the firing range. And that's where I came up with a game... It just so happened that we shot a lot — every two weeks there were firing exercises, sometimes by day, sometimes by night. The game was simple: two runs on the range, fifteen rounds each, three targets, two hits per target. Whoever used the fewest rounds, but not fewer than six, won. I shot well — otherwise I wouldn't have invented the game, knowing I'd be at a disadvantage. But others got the hang of it too, so we had to change the rules — still minimum rounds, but technically: exactly two per target, and with time measured too... The company sergeant major was unhappy, yelled at us, cursed — he didn't want to recount and hand in the leftovers after each of our sessions: “Idiots! Can't shoot for shit — they give you a magazine, so just fire it all into the air! I have to haul the crates back afterward!” But by then we had excitement. We played among ourselves, between squads, pair against pair, rookies against old-timers... Different ways. At first we played for butter, for sugar, for “who takes someone to the canteen,” but what did I care about food. I already understood how to arrange things and came up with a game for duty — the loser takes duty, the winner gets exempted from it... So I only worked duties during the first third of my service; after that I always tried to come out on top...

Some stalkers rush in blindly, wherever they can, like children. If you want guaranteed success, read the instructions, get maps, study the materials, develop your own system. And only then go in prepared... \nAfter the army I got a job, but my working career didn't last long. I had no desire to slave away from bell to bell, no interest, no motivation. You'd have to go to some boring job for a month, stare at the ceiling, and wait for payday just to blow it all in one evening and then spend another month in dull anticipation of the next paycheck... No thanks. That wasn't for me. But luck smiled on me. That day the first computer gaming club opened in our rundown town. Of course I couldn't miss such an event. And that's where I first learned that you could play poker online. That there were exchanges, clubs... and that it was all for real — real money, real bets, real winnings. That very day I bought all the manuals on card games from a little bookstore. Poker interested me the most. I began to study and drill everything thoroughly. But that wasn't enough, so I went online for instructions. I immersed myself in “studying.” Of course, I started going to the club, testing my strength, but at the same time I was developing “my system.” Before I started placing big bets, I had to be prepared...

There's a simple way to solve difficult everyday questions — it's called drawing lots. Flip a coin — heads or tails — a kind of handheld random number generator for decision-making, a simple game. Here in the Zone you often have to do it like that — go right or left... \nThat's how I got married, stupidly enough — I was used to blaming everything on fate. There was Lyubakha — so-so girl, but well-off; and there was Nadyukha — a great girl, but poor as dirt and with a whole harem of sisters. And I was full of doubts. I relied on chance — how the card would fall. So I cast lots and married Nadyukha. And then they all started sawing at me with their whole harem — this isn't enough, that isn't enough, you're this, you're that, you drag money out of the house for your games... That alone would've been tolerable, if not for the mother-in-law. If I met her now, I'd shoot her. A real sawmill, that one! “Parasite, loafer... Everyone else is like people, only you have nothing but games on your mind — a grown man, and you wear out your pants in clubs. If you were at least wasting your own money, but you don't bring in a penny and even drag it out of the house...” Damn it, that's all I remember from my whole “happy” family life. Nothing else comes to mind...

You can't lose track of time in the Zone. You need to know when night is coming — night is dangerous; you need to know when an emission is due and how long it will last. You have to calculate your strength if you take on a courier job, to make it on time. Time matters in the Zone... \nThe breath of the Internet touched me too, like many others. Life went on in waves, sometimes a white streak, sometimes a black one, depending on luck. But I managed to buy a computer and get connected. And then a completely different life began. Now I didn't have to go to the club to “work,” now I decided myself when my workday started and how long I could “work.” Sometimes I worked myself to exhaustion. One week I almost dropped dead. I spent a total of six days at the computer, eighteen hours each... I bet and won, then lost almost everything, then went all-in with the remainder and won again. I built up a huge bank, thought that just a little more and I'd leave the game — but the next draw wasn't mine and I crashed out... I swung like a pendulum, with rare breaks for four or five hours of sleep. I didn't cook anything for myself, drank tea and occasionally ordered pizza. It was as if I were tied to the computer — I was obsessed with the game, the thrill, the thirst for profit. The world around me didn't interest me, time stopped, I didn't know whether it was day or night outside... That week I wore myself out completely and left the game only because the connection was cut. Turns out I'd lost track of time and forgotten to pay the provider. They disconnected me. I collapsed exhausted and slept for a full day. Later, when I did the math, I realized I'd ended up with only a small bonus, like on the first day of the game. Turns out I could've quit back then already...

In my opinion, the main thing in the Zone isn't finding fat, rare artifacts, but managing to sell them quietly so you stay unnoticed. So no one understands why that stalker was poor as a church mouse and now lives it up. That means he's got something else. Where from? That means he needs to be felt out — made to share... \nLuck favors the prepared. I heard that phrase somewhere, in some movie. And it's true... One evening OMON stormed our “youth interest club.” They'd been tipped off that drug dealers were covering this gambling den. That didn't interest me much — I'd never messed with drugs. I wandered in out of old habit, to visit acquaintances. The only thing that interested me was the game, the thrill, the hope of success, that adrenaline that makes life not so dreary as it is outside the club. So they searched me on the way out and let me go, like everyone else who'd come just for interest... And so I'm walking home, taking the direct route — through the front garden; I already had a superstition about it — that path led to luck... I didn't immediately realize what I'd found, what kind of briefcase it was. But when I opened it... Yes! That was it! Luck. The bird of happiness. I always knew I'd catch it by the tail. I was ready to put it in my cage... It wasn't hard to piece things together — I understood perfectly what kind of money it was and why there was so much in one place, but I had no strength to refuse it. I held out for a week, then when I decided things had settled down, I started spending a little, then more, and then I went all out, living large... But how can you live with money and not gamble? Of course they noticed me — noticed the bets I was placing, sifted through the channels, matched events and facts, and also realized that the money hadn't fallen into my lap from the sky... After that everything was simple. A serious talk with serious people, a demand to return what was “not mine,” otherwise... By then I didn't even have a quarter of that amount left. And I decided to win it back. That day I put everything on the bank...

What draws people to the Zone more? The desire to run away from their problems, the thirst for adventure, or the wish to get rich quick, to grab a big haul?.. \nIf it were up to me, I'd never have come here voluntarily. What kind of idiot did you have to be to believe all those tales those guys were pouring into my ears at that apartment of the lame guy near Kyiv. One was pimply, the other reeked of tobacco — he smoked nonstop. Now I understand they were recruiters themselves, telling exactly what they needed to tell... But who needed it? Who are those gray figures that lure suckers like me here? And why did I, the fool, bite — I don't understand, for the life of me. My head was buzzing, my vision darkening, I was either drunk or drugged... And for some reason I wasn't afraid, I even believed them about fast, easy money, about a colossal jackpot you couldn't get in any other game. And that you didn't have to do anything — wealth would just fall into your hands. But I still can't understand who one of them was talking to when he said: “You'll work it off, kid, for your debts... And don't take what isn't yours. It's fine, you'll rise fast there... There's no point in a dead man, but this way you'll pay us back with interest, and for starters we'll take what you have — you'll sign a deed of gift.” What else they said, I can't remember. Seems we were drinking something, my vision was swimming, one of them was whispering something in my ear, and the other kept pushing some sheet of paper and a pen at me... it kept falling out of my hands, he'd pick it up, shove it back and keep pointing with his finger where to sign... No, if I'd been in my right mind back then, I'd never have come here...
